column2: kate, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: SEVERE PHOTOSENSITIVITY! Been on med 17 months. Nauseous every time I took it - 2X's p/d. Must take with food. Has caused serious severe photosensitivity.  In March - arms ,feet, and hands severely sunburned from unpacking boxes in sun for 2 hours.  Painful to touch, red with raised bumps. Cannot leave home w/o 50 Sunscreen.  June - just a few minutes of sun exposure (i.e.: walking from car to store) hands and feet burn even with sunscreen.  Can not drive with hands on top of car steering wheel, must keep them on bottom palms up. Large blood filled blisters developed on toes and had to be lanced.   Must keep feet covered at all times.  Knuckles are always red and burn, must apply sunscreen several times per day.  Had to stop med. Hopefully when out of my system photosensitivity will be too - but no guarantee!  Be very careful!

column2: 65-74 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Use of this drug was difficult. It was prescribed as a preventative course of action to protect from Lyme's Disease since I had been bitten by two ticks. The ticks were tested and were negative so the drug was unnecessary but had there been the Lyme's Disease present it would have warded off more serious symptoms by getting the drug into my system earlier.While I did not experience nausea, my stomach was affected. A couple of days into the 5 days course diarrhea started and although not consistent throughout the time I took it, that was followed by stomach pains after 4 days and continued a few days after stopping the drug. Since I take Prilosec for GERD I may have avoided the heartburn which some have complained about on this site. But, it is a drug to be avoided if something else will do for Lyme's. Zithromax, if appropriate, is a lot easier to tolerate and does not produce these symptoms.

I thought the first time my pain was from a physical injury to my chest because it takes a couple days for the ulcers to develop after you have the heartburn. This time I went to a clinic and am taking aciphex to help it heal. It has been about a week since my 2nd episode and the pain is just starting to let up a tiny bit. column2: bear, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have acne since in my teens.  I am now in my mid 30s.  I am currently taking doxycycline (100 mg cap) for one month and there is slight improvement to clearing my acne issue.  I take this med on empty stomach based on recommendation from this website to maximize the med full effectiveness.  The med did give me a slight headache but I was able to tolerate it.  If you can take it on an empty stomach, go for it.I have also read that the results will begin after six weeks, so be patient.  I have two more weeks to go.  I still have acne but it is less than one month ago.  I will report back in three to four weeks on my next result.  I cant wait until my face no longer has acne!I hope you will have good results.  Having acne sucks!  Good luck.

noticed results for my sinus infection w/i 12 hours!

column9: Doxycycline helped me when I had lyme disease because I haven't had any joint pain, donut rings on my arms, or any other symptoms I had during lyme disease. The only turn-off about the drug is I vomited after every time I took it because I didn't have a full stomach. I even ate oatmeal and other filling things and I still vomited. column2: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)

column9: I am still taking the medication for bronchitis. According to the prescription, I will be taking it for three more days. I have found that I have had to take this medication with food in order to avoid stomach upset. Yet, I have still had stomach upset and have contiplated discontinuing the medication. However, I eventually concluded that-for me-the benefits have outweighed the stomach upset. As a female, I have eaten yogurt when taking this medication in an effort to prevent a vaginal yeast infection. Also, I have learned that I need to drink more than 8 oz. of fluid when I take this medication. If I do not, I become miserable nauseated.

column2: mike, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: i am 21 years old. i've been suffering from acne since i was 16. nothing seemed to work in the past.. i was on proactive for a long while.. miserable results btw. then this past summer i went to a new dermatologist and i was prescribe 100mg of minocycline. my skin cleared up and stayed clear - i stopped thinking about it. for six months i lived the life i always wanted. this past winter break i went back to the Dr. and he said that i should alternate to Doxcycline (i think prolonged use of minocycline can have adverse effects). i've been on this new drug for only a week.. but i can already see my skin slipping back into its old ways. i'm hoping that this new medicine will start to work; however, i can't say i'm not a little pessimistic.. i can't go back to that old life. (most of you who are reading this understand what i'm talking about.) i'll post again in a week, hopefully with better news. i've decided to only give it 3 weeks, then i'm going back to minocycline. good luck to all. cheers! also if you have any info. that you'd like to send me please email me at mikeballer11@yahoo.com. thanks
